urls.title: The River Lea is plagued by pollution ‚Äì it is no place for a swim | Letters
urls.description: Letters: Readers respond to a photo essay on bathers in the River Lea at Hackney Marshes in east London

tweets.text:
"We do know that local volunteers are pulling sanitary waste out of the river just upstream of 'Hackney Beach'." The reality of England's rivers.

And the @EnvAgency does what exactly?

https://t.co/rdKF8KpJFu

@Feargal_Sharkey @RosieP4 @EnvAgency It's so disheartening to see that. I just took a walk along my local river that is covered is sewage pollution. üòû the culprit.. @AnglianWater sewage works further along the river.

Thousands of litres of possibly contaminated water from an HS2 site will pass along this ditch and go straight into the River Colne, a chalk stream already under immense pressure. Disastrous.
@GeorgeMonbiot @bwebster135 @BBCPanorama @RiverChess @EnvAgency , @Chilternstreams https://t.co/4OY9TSIoPd

tweets.text: Escaping our home because the @EnvAgency won‚Äôt #stopthestink from Red industries Walley‚Äôs Quarry. Can‚Äôt open our windows with hail and snow. Can‚Äôt stay in our home @StinkStopthe @SimonTagg @AaronBell4NUL https://t.co/MFHx08b80I

@lucyb221 @RedIndustries2 @StinkStopthe @AaronBell4NUL @SimonTagg I love around 2.5 miles (by road) from the quarry, in Clayton, and this morning when I took the dog out, the smell was awful. It was making my eyes water and I had to use my inhaler as I am asthmatic.
I cannot imagine what it must be like closer to the quarry. Needs sorting ASAP
@ben_watt @BarnetCouncil @VeoliaUK @welshharpies @silkstreamers @CanalRiverTrust @NaturalEngland Amazing effort. Will make sure the area is on our hit list for a deep clean #volunteers

tweets.text: So, now we all agree that there is a stink (a.k.a. H2S gas at sufficient levels to breach WHO health guidelines!), what are the chances of actually doing something about it? Gassed in my home again! @EnvAgencyMids @AaronBell4NUL @NewsNBC @StinkStopthe @WHO @bbcmtd  #StopTheStink

@amorexplore @hackneycouncil @TheBrokedownPal @EnvAgency Thank you. Yes, we know too little about what ends up in the Lea. More rain will mean pollution washed off the roads into the rivers (from 80 square miles of paved surfaces). 
With no live sewer spill alerts from Thames Water we're left to guess if they'll start discharging.
